clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Study of the Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction (ED) With Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy (ESWT)
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomised, Blinded, Placebo-controlled Pilot Study of the Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction With Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy (ESWT)

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of the pilot study is to assess the feasibility of a full randomised, placebo-controlled clinical trial.The aim is to demonstrate that penile shockwave application in patients with erectile dysfunction of vascular origin leads to a greater increase in potency than in the control group.

clinical_study.why_stopped: It has been decided to improve the inclusion criteria for better study outcome

primary_outcome.measure: Effects of erection problems on the sex life (International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire)

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of erection (Quality of Erection Questionnaire)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At screening, 1, 3 and 6 months post treatment

arm_group.description: Shock waves are applied extracorporeally with 0.1 millijoule per square millimeter (mJ/mm2)
Shock waves are prohibited to enter the body by placebo stand-off.

intervention.description: extracorporeal shock waves: Verum: 0.1 mJ/mm2 Placebo: placebo stand-off

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Erectile dysfunction for more than 6 months
- Informed consent
- Positive effect of phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor (PDE5i)
- IIEF-15 score less than 20
- No neurological disease
- Stable partnership for more than 3 months
- Age 18-75
Exclusion Criteria:
- Total prostatectomy
- Another reason for ED except for vascular disorder
- Clinically significant hematological disease
- Heart stroke, Arrythmia during the last 6 months
- Cancer during the last 5 years
- Intake of antiandrogen
- ED treatment with the last 7 days
- IIEF score higher than, equal to 20
- Previous shockwave treatment
